questions.text: A researcher investigates the pathway that activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system via the juxtaglomerular (JG) apparatus. Which of the following is a component of the juxtaglomerular apparatus?

choices.text: Macula densa in the distal convoluted tubule
The cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Principal cells of the collecting ducts
Alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
The juxtaglomerular apparatus is a specialized structure that consists of a group of cells from the distal convoluted tubule or DCT (macula densa) and the glomerular afferent arteriole (mesangial cells and juxtaglomerular cells or JG cells, which are modified smooth muscle cells). Its primary function is to regulate blood pressure and the filtration rate of the glomerulus.
   
  • The JG cells secrete renin when the blood pressure in the arteriole falls by increased sympathetic tone (beta-1). Renin increases blood pressure via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.  
  • Macula densa are specialized chemoreceptor cells in the wall of the DCT which sense the delivery of sodium and chloride ions. When the blood pressure is low, it decreases renal perfusion and glomerular filtration of sodium and chloride ions, thus delivering to macula densa. These cells then secrete prostaglandins to signal JG cells to secrete renin.  
  • Lacis cells, extraglomerular mesangial cells, are flat and elongated cells near the macula densa. Their function remains unclear. 

Option Analysis

✅ Macula densa in the distal convoluted tubule:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The cotransport system (Na+/K+/2Cl−) of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle:
Incorrect: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is not a part of the JG apparatus. The cotransport system is the site of action of loop diuretics (e.g. furosemide).  
❌ Principal cells of the collecting ducts:
Incorrect: Principal cells of the collecting ducts are not a part of the JG apparatus. When stimulated by aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH), these cells are involved in sodium and water reabsorption and potassium secretion when stimulated by aldosterone and antidiuretic hormone (ADH).  
❌ Alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: Alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule are not a part of the JG apparatus. These cells are involved in hydrogen (H+) ion secretion when stimulated by aldosterone by upregulating H+ ATPase activity.  
❌ Cells of proximal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: Cells of proximal convoluted tubule are not a part of the JG apparatus.

questions.text: To understand the process of glomerular filtration, a group of researchers examine several molecules which cannot undergo filtration. One molecule that does not undergo filtration is albumin. Which of the following contributes to the glomerulus' inability to freely filter albumin?

choices.text: Negative electric charge of the basement membrane
Positive electrical charge of the basement membrane
Negative electrical charge of the endothelial cells
The size of the pores in endothelial cells
Negative electrical charge of podocyte foot processes.

questions.solution:
The glomerular filtration system barrier comprises three structures that allow blood filtration but prevent large molecules like erythrocytes and plasma proteins from being filtered.  

  1. Endothelial cells: These cells have pores that allow the passage of fluid and plasma electrolytes and proteins but prevent the passage of larger molecules like erythrocytes.   
  2. The basement membrane: The basement membrane has smaller pores that only allow the passage of certain substances (e.g., sodium, water) but are too small for plasma proteins to pass through (e.g. albumin). Additionally, the basement membrane is negatively charged, preventing negatively charged molecules (e.g. albumin) from being filtered.   
  3. The podocytes: are specialized epithelial cells that wrap around the basement membrane. These cells contain filtration slits, tiny gaps that form a barrier against the filtration of large molecules, including proteins.   


Option Analysis

✅ Negative electric charge of the basement membrane  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Positive electrical charge of the basement membrane:
Incorrect: The basement membrane is negatively charged and thus repels negatively-charged molecules, including albumin.  
❌ Negative electrical charge of the endothelial cells  :
Incorrect: The endothelial cells are not negatively charged
❌ The size of the pores in endothelial cells  :
Incorrect: The pores in the endothelial cells are large enough to filter albumin freely.  
❌ Negative electrical charge of podocyte foot processes.  :
Incorrect: Podocytes are not negatively charged.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the physiologic changes of urine as it passes through the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). Which of the following is true regarding the functions and transporters of DCT?

choices.text: Parathyroid hormone stimulates the Ca2+/Na exchange on the DCT
65-80% of sodium is reabsorbed in the DCT
Sodium hydrogen exchange is regulated by aldosterone
Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the DCT

questions.solution:
The distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is lined by tubule cells. It is divided into:

Early DCT: Channels and their functions are summarized below:
  1. Na+Cl- cotransporter (on the apical surface): Moves sodium down its concentration gradient and uses this energy to move one chloride ion. Cl- moves into the interstitium down its concentration gradient via basolateral chloride channels. 
  2. Calcium channels on the apical surface 
  3. Na-Ca2+ channels on the basolateral surface regulated by parathyroid hormone: moves sodium into the tubular cells to increase the gradient for calcium reabsorption. 
  4. Na+-K+ ATPase: pumps 3 Na+ out of the cell and lets 2 K+ ions into the cell from the interstitium, which helps to maintain low intracellular sodium levels. 
Normally, the early DCT reabsorbs about 5% of the filtered sodium, but this reabsorption is load-dependent.
 

Late DCT and collecting duct consists of principal cells and α-intercalated cells dispersed among the tubule cells.

  1.  Principal cells: 
  • ENaC that allows sodium into the cell, and
  • a potassium channel that allows potassium into the lumen
  • Na/K ATPase pump on the basolateral surface

      2.  Intercalated cells have:

  • H+/ATPase: uses ATP to pump hydrogen into the tubule against its concentration gradient
  • Hydrogen potassium ATPase: uses ATP to push 1 hydrogen into the tubule in exchange for 1 potassium, both against their concentration gradients
  • Na/K ATPase pump on the basolateral surface

The late DCT and collecting duct is hormonally regulated by aldosterone, which acts on ENaC, ATP-dependent potassium pump, and the Na-K ATPase transporter.  

Option Analysis

❌ It is impermeable to sodium:
Incorrect: The thin descending loop of Henle is impermeable to sodium. The early distal convoluted tubule is impermeable to water.  
✅ Parathyroid hormone stimulates the Ca2+/Na exchange on the DCT:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 65-80% of sodium is reabsorbed in the DCT:
Incorrect: Around 67% of the sodium that gets filtered into the tubular fluid is reabsorbed in the PCT. Only 5-10% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the DCT.  
❌ Sodium hydrogen exchange is regulated by aldosterone:
Incorrect: Sodium is reabsorbed in exchange for hydrogen and potassium ions excretion in the collecting duct and is regulated by aldosterone.  
❌ Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the DCT:
Incorrect: Na-K-2Cl channel is located on the apical surface of the thick ascending loop of Henle.

questions.text: A study is performed to determine the volume of water found in different body compartments. In the study, an indicator-dilution method using labeled inulin was used. The volume calculated from the inulin-dilution method represents one of the following?
questions.solution:
The human body comprises approximately 60% water, which is distributed into different compartments: the intracellular compartment, interstitial fluid, and plasma.  

To measure the volume of different compartments, the indicator-dilution method is used. Where a measurable substance is injected into the body and distributed in the compartment of interest, the volume of that specific compartment can be measured based on the equation: Volume (V) = Amount (substance injected)/Concentration). Different substances can be used to calculate the volume of different compartments based on the features of that substance:  

  • The extracellular fluid volume: Labeled inulin or mannitol can be used to measure the extracellular fluid volume directly. These substances distribute between the plasma and the interstitial fluid but are too large to cross the cell membrane.  
  • The plasma volume: radiolabeled albumin can measure the plasma volume as it only stays in the plasma and does not cross to the interstitial fluid or the intracellular space.  
  • The interstitial fluid cannot be measured directly but can be calculated indirectly by subtracting the plasma volume from the extracellular fluid volume.  
  • Total body water (TBW): TBW can be measured using radiolabeled titrated water, which distributes in all three compartments.  
  • The intracellular fluid volume: Cannot be measured directly but indirectly by subtracting the extracellular fluid volume from the total body water.  

Option Analysis

✅ The extracellular fluid volume  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The plasma volume  :
Incorrect: Inulin distributes between plasma and interstitial fluid; therefore, the volume calculation will account for both, not just plasma volume.  
❌ The intracellular fluid volume  :
Incorrect: Inulin is a large molecule that does not diffuse across cell membranes. It, therefore, measures the extracellular volume.  
❌ The interstitial fluid volume  :
Incorrect: Inulin distributes between plasma and interstitial fluid and measures both fluid volumes, not only the interstitial fluid volume.  
❌ Total body fluid volume  :
Incorrect: Because inulin is a large molecule, it cannot measure the intracellular volume as it does not diffuse across cell membranes. Radioactive titrated water distributes in the intracellular and extracellular compartments and can be used to measure the total body water.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the pathophysiology of brain natriuretic peptides (BNP). This peptide is released from the heart's ventricles in response to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are two peptide molecules secreted by the atria and ventricles of the heart, respectively, in response to increased cardiac workload when the walls of the atria and ventricles are stretched (as in fluid overload states like congestive heart failure).

BNP and ANP bind to surface receptors on the vascular smooth muscle of afferent and efferent arterioles. They relax afferent arterioles via cGMP and constrict efferent arterioles increasing glomerular filtration rate (GFR). A rise in GFR causes increased sodium (Na+) filtration with no compensatory sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron. Increased sodium ion delivery to the distal convoluted tubule is sensed by the macula densa, which results in downregulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). The net effect is sodium loss and, by osmosis, water loss, ultimately diminished fluid overloaded states.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased plasma aldosterone:
Incorrect: Aldosterone increases sodium and water reabsorption in volume-depleted states. It has no role in the release of BNP.  
❌ Increased plasma dopamine:
Incorrect: Dopamine, apart from acting as a neurotransmitter, acts on dopamine receptors in the heart and kidneys, where it induces vasodilation in volume-depleted states. It has no role in the release of BNP.  
✅ Diminished cardiac ejection fraction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decline in renal perfusion:
Incorrect: Decline in renal perfusion decreases stretch in afferent arterioles, reduces sodium delivery to macula densa, and activates the sympathetic nervous system, activating the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). It has no role in the release of BNP.  
❌ Increased antidiuretic hormone (ADH):
Incorrect: Secretion of ADH is stimulated by angiotensin II in volume-depleted states. ADH acts on the principal cells of the collecting ducts of nephrons to reabsorb water. It has no role in the release of BNP.

questions.text: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen block the action of prostaglandins on afferent arterioles in the kidney. Which of the following changes in renal function are observed with NSAID use?
questions.solution:
The kidneys produce prostaglandin E2 and prostaglandin I2 in response to sympathetic stimulation. Both molecules dilate the afferent and efferent arterioles to ensure renal blood flow doesn’t get too low during fight-or-flight situations.

Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are commonly used medications associated with nephrotoxicity when consumed chronically or in high doses. NSAID action involves cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme inhibition, interfering with arachidonic acid conversion into E2 prostaglandins E2, prostacyclins, and thromboxanes. In the absence of prostaglandin, unopposed vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles occurs, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF). This change does not affect the filtration fraction, which is defined as the ratio of GFR/RPF.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Constriction of the ureter can decrease GFR without affecting the RPF; however, this does not describe the effects of NSAID use on kidney function.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Efferent arteriole constriction (e.g. by angiotensin II) can increase the GFR and decrease renal plasma flow, leading to an increase in filtration fraction.   
❌ :
Incorrect: A decrease in serum plasma protein decreases oncotic pressure and results in more fluid being filtered via the kidney, thus increasing the GFR and thereby FF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Dehydration decreases the RPF more than the GFR and thereby increases the FF.

questions.text: During states of reduced renal blood flow, angiotensin II is produced. Which of the following best describes the effect of angiotensin II on the kidney?
questions.solution:
During reduced renal plasma flow states, renin is released from granular cells within the wall of the afferent arteriole in a region called the juxtaglomerular apparatus. Renin, a proteolytic enzyme, catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE).

Angiotensin II promotes vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole, resulting in increased glomerular hydrostatic pressure and subsequently elevated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and reduced renal plasma flow (RPF). The overall effect is an increase in filtration fraction (FF), which is the ratio of GFR/RPF.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Constriction of the ureter can decrease GFR without affecting the RPF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: In the absence of prostaglandin, unopposed vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles occurs, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF). This change does not affect the filtration fraction, which is defined as the ratio of GFR/RPF.   
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation   
❌ :
Incorrect: A decrease in serum plasma protein decreases oncotic pressure and results in more fluid being filtered via the kidney, thus increasing the GFR and thereby FF.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Dehydration decreases the RPF more than the GFR and thereby increases the FF.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the pathway that results in the generation of angiotensin II. Which of the following factors activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)?

choices.text: Increased sodium chloride delivery to the distal convoluted tubule

questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is one of the mechanisms by which the cardiovascular system and kidneys attempt to maintain normal arterial blood pressure by controlling blood volume. When blood is supplied to the renal artery, it reaches the afferent arterioles. In the walls of the afferent arterioles are specialized smooth muscle cells called juxtaglomerular (JG) cells which secrete renin when stimulated.

There are mainly three mechanisms by which JG cells are stimulated to secrete renin:
 
  1. Renal mechanoreceptors: JG cells are designed to sense pressure as blood flows through the juxtaglomerular apparatus mechanically. When they are stretched from increasing blood pressure, renin release becomes inhibited. In contrast, low blood pressure stimulates renin release. 
  2. Sympathetic nervous system: JG cells are supplied by sympathetic nerve fibers. When mechanoreceptors at the aortic arch collapse from low blood pressure, they activate the sympathetic nervous system and stimulate the beta-1 adrenergic receptors found on JG cells to secrete renin. 
  3. Macula densa: Macula densa are specialized chemoreceptor cells found in the wall of the distal convoluted tubule and detect concentrations of sodium and chloride ions. When the blood pressure is low, decreased renal perfusion and glomerular filtration results in reduced-sodium and chloride ions and thus macula densa. The cells of the macula densa then secrete prostaglandins to signal to JG cells to secrete renin. 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypotension, not hypertension, results in activation of the RAAS.  
✅ Sympathetic stimulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased sodium chloride delivery to the distal convoluted tubule:
Incorrect: Decreased (not increased) sodium chloride delivery to distal convoluted tubules is sensed by chemoreceptors of the macula densa in the juxta glomerular apparatus, which results in activation of the RAAS.  
❌ Atrial natriuretic peptide:
Incorrect: Atrial natriuretic peptide is released from the heart's atria in response to increased circulating volume (as in congestive heart failure). Atrial natriuretic peptide inhibits, not activates, RAAS.  
❌ Brain natriuretic peptide:
Incorrect: Brain natriuretic peptide is released from the heart's ventricles in response to increased volume (as in congestive heart failure). Brain natriuretic peptide inhibits, not activates, RAAS.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the mechanisms of potassium homeostasis. They find that potassium movement across the cell membrane is controlled by many factors. Which of the following increases the movement of potassium from the intracellular space to the extracellular space?
questions.solution:
Potassium is one of the body's most important ions; the slightest change in plasma potassium concentration can potentially lead to catastrophic results. Most potassium in the body is stored within cells. The movement of potassium across the cell membrane is affected by many factors.

The main channel that helps maintain high intracellular potassium concentrations is the sodium-potassium ATPase pump (Na+/K+ ATPase pump), which pumps potassium into cells while pushing sodium out of cells.

Many factors affect blood potassium concentration through their effect on the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. For instance, insulin and catecholamines increase the activity of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, thereby shifting potassium inside the cell. Metabolic alkalosis also increases the movement of potassium inside the cell because H+ ions are pushed into the blood in exchange for potassium ions that enter the cells. Finally, decreased plasma osmolarity causes water to move into the cells, which draws potassium with it, shifting potassium inside the cell.

In contrast, factors that increase the movement of potassium out of the cell include increased plasma osmolarity. Increased plasma osmolarity causes water to move out of the cells, drawing potassium. Also, in metabolic acidosis, H+ moves inside the cell, and potassium is excreted out of the cell. Other factors that increase the movement of potassium into the extracellular space include insulin deficiency (e.g. diabetes mellitus type I), beta-blockers, digoxin (blocks the Na+/K+ ATPase pump), and cellular lysis enabling intracellular potassium to leak into the circulation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased plasma osmolarity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metabolic alkalosis:
Incorrect: In metabolic alkalosis, H+ ions are excreted from the cell to neutralize the blood pH in exchange for potassium ions. Therefore, metabolic alkalosis leads to a net shift of potassium into cells.  
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: Insulin increases the activity of the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, thereby shifting potassium into the cells.  
❌ Catecholamines:
Incorrect: Catecholamines also increase the activity of the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, thereby shifting potassium into the cells.  
❌ Decreased plasma osmolarity:
Incorrect: Decreased plasma osmolarity shifts potassium into the cells.

questions.text: A researcher studies the process of glucose filtration and reabsorption at normal plasma concentrations and at higher plasma concentrations. Which of the following is true regarding how the kidneys filter and reabsorb glucose at different plasma concentrations?

choices.text: All filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules at normal plasma glucose levels
Glucose is excreted in the urine regardless of plasma glucose concentration
Glucose is actively secreted into the tubular lumen of the proximal convoluted tubule at higher plasma concentrations
Glucose is not filtered by the kidney at normal plasma concentrations
Filtered glucose is always reabsorbed regardless of the plasma concentration

questions.solution:
Glucose is a major component of the human diet and the main source of energy for the body. Glucose gets filtered in the glomerulus along with other molecules, and the amount of filtered glucose is directly proportional to the plasma concentration of glucose. As the plasma concentration of glucose increases, so does filtered glucose in the kidneys.

At normal plasma concentrations of glucose, all filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules. This is accomplished by special transporters found within tubular cells. At the apical surface, tubular cells have a specialized transporter called the sodium-glucose linked transporter (SGLT), which uses the electrochemical gradient of sodium to move glucose from the tubular lumen against their concentration gradient. Glucose is then transported into the blood by specialized glucose transporters called GLUT 1 or GLUT 2.

At higher plasma concentrations, filtered glucose increases, and saturates SGLT transporters, resulting in glucosuria.  


Option Analysis

✅ All filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules at normal plasma glucose levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glucose is excreted in the urine regardless of plasma glucose concentration:
Incorrect: At normal plasma concentrations, all filtered glucose is reabsorbed. At higher plasma concentrations, glucose carriers saturate with remaining glucose excreted in urine.  
❌ Glucose is actively secreted into the tubular lumen of the proximal convoluted tubule at higher plasma concentrations:
Incorrect: Glucose is not actively secreted in the proximal convoluted tubule.  
❌ Glucose is not filtered by the kidney at normal plasma concentrations:
Incorrect: Glucose is filtered in the glomerulus. At normal plasma concentrations, all filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubules.  
❌ Filtered glucose is always reabsorbed regardless of the plasma concentration:
Incorrect:  At normal plasma concentrations, all filtered glucose is reabsorbed. At higher plasma concentrations, glucose carriers saturate with remaining glucose excreted in urine.
